content: I recently had the honor and privilege of meeting several WWII veterans, one of whom fought on Iwo Jima, one of whom fought at Guadalcanal. As I listened to their stories and tales, and shared a few of my own experiences, I began to feel that military service today is somehow different than it was back then. I have been in for 7 years now, and I always try to see the best in people and in this organization. But maybe I am starting to get a bit jaded. I get so frustrated at all the privileges that have now become RIGHTS. You can't punish a knucklehead without making sure his feelings don't get hurt. You can't PT your Marines without making sure a Corpsman is present and that you have ORM'd the whole thing to death. You can't call a spade a spade without making sure that someone's feathers don't get ruffled. I have always said that there is a fine line between a bureaucrat and a public servant. I think many of today's "professional soldiers" are much closer to the bureaucrat side of the house. The men and women of WWI and WWII (and Korea and Vietnam to a great extent too) understood the value of sacrifice, and what it meant to be a servant. They didn't do it for the pay, the benefits, the privileges, or the glory. They did it because it had to be done and done well. I try to PME my young troops by teaching them about their Marine ancestors. Hopefully, one or two of them will "get it". [/Soap Box] "Common sense was an uncommon virtue"

content: I'm not sure the urge to serve has ever been all that great in this country, at least not to the extent your post suggests. Look back at our history and you'll find very, very few people who volunteered for military service for that reason and that was often a family matter. Some families provide huge numbers of soldiers, some never do, and most only during a time of extreme crisis, such as the Civil War or WWII. Every major conflict we ever fought required our citizens to be compelled to serve, except for this one. Typically, there was a surge of voluntary enlistments at the beginning, but that rapidly tapered off and a draft became necessary. Even then, men went to extreme lengths to avoid being drafted. In periods of our history when there was no draft, enlistees were typically on the run from the law and hiding out in the service. The latter day Indian wars, for instance, were almost exclusively fought by the dregs of society who were either forced into the Army or running from something. Even as far back as the War of 1812, we had militia troops who flat refused to follow Winfield Scott into Canada because that wasn't what they signed up to do. And, nobody made them go either! In the Revolution, Washington had trouble keeping his Army manned because when their enlistment was up, they tended to go home. The bottom line is this: Don't judge American soldiers by today's standards. The modern version of the all volunteer force is unique in our history and probably doomed to failure for the very reason that, as in all things American, we do what suits us best, personally, and service to our fellow man isn't, and never has been, a high priority for most of us.

content: Keep in mind that WW-II is beginning on the heels of the Great Depression, and opportunities are slim (college is not available for many as it is today), the nation was divided over isolationism... many facts shaped the minds and attitudes of young men then, including the draft and very heavy propaganda (very different from today.) Would I want us to gallop back to the 1940s mentality or the 1950s? No, those were not the "perfect" times and we have actually progressed. As far as noticing the difference between my service time 45+ years ago and today, I feel there is more for military members and their ability to advance themselves. Much better deal than in my days. IMHO

content: I entered the U.S. Army in 1969, enlisting to avoid the draft and the 50% chance I could be involutarily put in the Marine Corps. I left active service in 1975 and entered the Army Reserves, retiring in 1995. So I can only speak to what I experienced during that period. The Army of 1995 was very different from the Army of 1969. The draft made it more racialy and regionally diverse, and it was not unusual to have some highly educated men serving their two years service (via the draft) in combat arms while the draft was in effect. When the draft ended, the Army became less Caucasian, less educated and more from either the Deep South and the Rust Belt of Ohio, Indiana, etc. The more blatant examples of racism that I has seen in 1969 started to fade away as the percentage of non-Caucasians increased, but as the percentage of Jews and Catholics decreased after the draft, anti-semitism and anti-Catholicism within the military increased. (For example, a Fundamentalist Protestant 1SG in my battalion [circa 1975] always skewed his company's duty roster so that the two Jewish enlisted in his company always seem to get duty [guard, CQ, etc.] on Friday nights so that they couldn't attend temple. But he would always ensure that the fundamentalist Protestants in his unit were never on duty Wednesday nights so that they could go with him to fundamentalist Protestant prayer meetings.) The power of the Pass was a great club that NCO's had over their enlisted men - but it was often abused. (For those who don't remember, a service member had to have a Pass to get off the Base on evenings or on weekends, and access to that Pass was controlled by your NCO or Officer.) I can't say how things have changed since I retired 13 years ago - I hope they have improved for the better. This message has been edited. Last edited by: Fightdirector, Mon 11 May 2009 11:41 AM

content: I wondered about the "new" Army too, until I visited my son at Ft. Benning back in 1996, where he was undergoing Infantry OSUT. The first thing I noticed was that the Drill's looked just like the Drill's I had in 1969 and just like the ones I served with as a Drill in the 70's. They didn't cuss the troops like we did and abuse them, but they were training them and training them well. The next thing I noticed was that the trainees looked just like the ones I'd known before too. They each had that deer in the headlights look and didn't appear to be any brighter, or dumber, than the ones I'd pushed a generation before. Some were dedicated soldiers, some were lost without Mommy and some would push their boundries just as far as they could. Nothing new there; move on. The final straw occured while I was talking to my son during a break in training at his Starship. Over his shoulder, I saw the Senior Drill step out of the orderly room and put a whistle in his mouth. When he blew that thing, my son vaporized right in front of me, leaving words hanging in mid-air, and he was in formation before I knew what was happening. "YES!" I said to myself. That was EXACTLY what I wanted to see! Ever since then, I have no qualms or trepidations about putting the security of our country in the hands of the current generation. They are receiving excellent training and are as motivated and tough as any soldiers I've ever seen. Yeah, they may look funny off duty, with their tatoos and baggy pants, but when the time comes, they're there and doing a magnificent job.

content: I recently had the honor and privilege of meeting several WWII veterans, one of whom fought on Iwo Jima, one of whom fought at Guadalcanal. As I listened to their stories and tales, and shared a few of my own experiences, I began to feel that military service today is somehow different than it was back then. I have been in for 7 years now, and I always try to see the best in people and in this organization. But maybe I am starting to get a bit jaded. I get so frustrated at all the privileges that have now become RIGHTS. You can't punish a knucklehead without making sure his feelings don't get hurt. You can't PT your Marines without making sure a Corpsman is present and that you have ORM'd the whole thing to death. You can't call a spade a spade without making sure that someone's feathers don't get ruffled. I have always said that there is a fine line between a bureaucrat and a public servant. I think many of today's "professional soldiers" are much closer to the bureaucrat side of the house. The men and women of WWI and WWII (and Korea and Vietnam to a great extent too) understood the value of sacrifice, and what it meant to be a servant. They didn't do it for the pay, the benefits, the privileges, or the glory. They did it because it had to be done and done well. I try to PME my young troops by teaching them about their Marine ancestors. Hopefully, one or two of them will "get it". [/Soap Box] "Common sense was an uncommon virtue"

content: I'm not sure the urge to serve has ever been all that great in this country, at least not to the extent your post suggests. Look back at our history and you'll find very, very few people who volunteered for military service for that reason and that was often a family matter. Some families provide huge numbers of soldiers, some never do, and most only during a time of extreme crisis, such as the Civil War or WWII. Every major conflict we ever fought required our citizens to be compelled to serve, except for this one. Typically, there was a surge of voluntary enlistments at the beginning, but that rapidly tapered off and a draft became necessary. Even then, men went to extreme lengths to avoid being drafted. In periods of our history when there was no draft, enlistees were typically on the run from the law and hiding out in the service. The latter day Indian wars, for instance, were almost exclusively fought by the dregs of society who were either forced into the Army or running from something. Even as far back as the War of 1812, we had militia troops who flat refused to follow Winfield Scott into Canada because that wasn't what they signed up to do. And, nobody made them go either! In the Revolution, Washington had trouble keeping his Army manned because when their enlistment was up, they tended to go home. The bottom line is this: Don't judge American soldiers by today's standards. The modern version of the all volunteer force is unique in our history and probably doomed to failure for the very reason that, as in all things American, we do what suits us best, personally, and service to our fellow man isn't, and never has been, a high priority for most of us.

content: Keep in mind that WW-II is beginning on the heels of the Great Depression, and opportunities are slim (college is not available for many as it is today), the nation was divided over isolationism... many facts shaped the minds and attitudes of young men then, including the draft and very heavy propaganda (very different from today.) When he would visit me in the 1960s in the service he noted it was a world of difference (I didn't think so, but he could see it.) For the past 15 years I have been a civilian instructor in the military. Frequently I hear the senior NCO's lament "What's wrong with these young people today?"... year after year. The basic difference is that people born after 1960s have little to no memory of "authority". It's neither good nor bad but it does 'color' the mind set of service members. Would I want us to gallop back to the 1940s mentality or the 1950s? No, those were not the "perfect" times and we have actually progressed. As far as noticing the difference between my service time 45+ years ago and today, I feel there is more for military members and their ability to advance themselves. Much better deal than in my days. content: I entered the U.S. Army in 1969, enlisting to avoid the draft and the 50% chance I could be involutarily put in the Marine Corps. I left active service in 1975 and entered the Army Reserves, retiring in 1995. So I can only speak to what I experienced during that period. The Army of 1995 was very different from the Army of 1969. The draft made it more racialy and regionally diverse, and it was not unusual to have some highly educated men serving their two years service (via the draft) in combat arms while the draft was in effect. When the draft ended, the Army became less Caucasian, less educated and more from either the Deep South and the Rust Belt of Ohio, Indiana, etc. The more blatant examples of racism that I has seen in 1969 started to fade away as the percentage of non-Caucasians increased, but as the percentage of Jews and Catholics decreased after the draft, anti-semitism and anti-Catholicism within the military increased. (For example, a Fundamentalist Protestant 1SG in my battalion [circa 1975] always skewed his company's duty roster so that the two Jewish enlisted in his company always seem to get duty [guard, CQ, etc.] on Friday nights so that they couldn't attend temple. But he would always ensure that the fundamentalist Protestants in his unit were never on duty Wednesday nights so that they could go with him to fundamentalist Protestant prayer meetings.) The power of the Pass was a great club that NCO's had over their enlisted men - but it was often abused. (For those who don't remember, a service member had to have a Pass to get off the Base on evenings or on weekends, and access to that Pass was controlled by your NCO or Officer.) I can't say how things have changed since I retired 13 years ago - I hope they have improved for the better. This message has been edited. Last edited by: Fightdirector, Mon 11 May 2009 11:41 AM

content: I wondered about the "new" Army too, until I visited my son at Ft. Benning back in 1996, where he was undergoing Infantry OSUT. The first thing I noticed was that the Drill's looked just like the Drill's I had in 1969 and just like the ones I served with as a Drill in the 70's. They didn't cuss the troops like we did and abuse them, but they were training them and training them well. The next thing I noticed was that the trainees looked just like the ones I'd known before too. They each had that deer in the headlights look and didn't appear to be any brighter, or dumber, than the ones I'd pushed a generation before. Some were dedicated soldiers, some were lost without Mommy and some would push their boundries just as far as they could. Nothing new there; move on. The final straw occured while I was talking to my son during a break in training at his Starship. Over his shoulder, I saw the Senior Drill step out of the orderly room and put a whistle in his mouth. When he blew that thing, my son vaporized right in front of me, leaving words hanging in mid-air, and he was in formation before I knew what was happening. "YES!" I said to myself. That was EXACTLY what I wanted to see! Ever since then, I have no qualms or trepidations about putting the security of our country in the hands of the current generation. They are receiving excellent training and are as motivated and tough as any soldiers I've ever seen. Yeah, they may look funny off duty, with their tatoos and baggy pants, but when the time comes, they're there and doing a magnificent job.
